WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. Emma Howlett
Address 2815 Angers St., Regina
Birthplace Sweden

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS (Most of information refers to period 1905-1912)
   What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1918 (married)
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Gary, Sask.
   Where had you been living before that? Chicago, Ill.
   For how many people did you prepare meals? Two (after 1918)
   How far was it to your nearest store?
   How often could a visit be made to the store?
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

Before marriage my home was 15 miles from Milestone 3. A horse & buggy trip was made to Milestone 3 only twice during the summer for supplies. The men hauling grain in the winter brought supplies until 1912.

Dear Sir:

I have been able to get my older sister to fill out as much as she could of your questionnaire. On many points she remembers no details. Other wise in her teens in the period after 1905, she herself was not actively housekeeping until 1918, but she remembers much of the housekeeping of her mother (and mine) home.

I hope this will help you more to you in the study of early diet, which is contemplated. Incidentally, I might say that, as it was impossible for us to get Kellogg's products often we came here from the States, it affected my father's health, and helped to cause his untimely death at the age of 49. He had been able to get these foods in Chicago, and was much better down there for that reason. And thus in knowledge we have from our family history, it isn't necessarily what a letter tells us. It was an experience for knowing the facts of our own food supply.

I hope you understand my point from.

Sincerely,

C.T. Holstrom
Dear Sirs:

I have been able to get my dear wife a
full set of music in the form of 60 records. God
willing she will be able to play them in the Grand
Hotel next summer. I am enclosing a copy of the
bill of sale.

The northern lights are very beautiful at
night and still is an impressive sight. God
willing we shall be able to see them from
here.

Let us hope that you will be able to come
back soon. We miss you very much.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
R.T. Halloran
Oxford
